This JavaScript file defines a [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") component in React, a popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces. The [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") component is a higher-order component that wraps other components, providing a consistent structure to the pages of your application.

At the top of the file, two other components, [`Header`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FHeader.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Header.js") and [`Footer`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FFooter.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Footer.js"), are imported. These components are likely to contain the content for the header and footer sections of your application, respectively.

The [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") component itself is a functional component that takes one prop: [`children`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A16%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js"). In React, [`children`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A16%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") is a special prop that is used to pass components as data to other components. This is a powerful feature that makes your components more reusable. In this case, any components wrapped by [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") will be passed as [`children`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A16%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js").

Inside the [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") component, a fragment (`<>...</>`) is returned. Fragments let you group a list of children without adding extra nodes to the DOM. This fragment contains the [`Header`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FHeader.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Header.js") component, the [`children`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A16%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") passed to [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js"), and the [`Footer`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FFooter.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Footer.js") component, in that order. This means that any [`children`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A16%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") passed to [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") will be rendered between the [`Header`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FHeader.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Header.js") and [`Footer`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FFooter.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Footer.js").

Finally, the [`Layout`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fwebsite%2Fcomponents%2FLayout.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A3%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D "website/components/Layout.js") component is exported so that it can be imported and used in other parts of your application.

parts.text: where to see the main content

response.value:
The main content of the page is displayed between the `
` and `
` components in the `Layout` component. It's represented by the `{children}` prop. This `children` prop is a special prop in React that is used to display whatever you include between the opening and closing tags when invoking a component. So, wherever you use the `Layout` component in your application and pass JSX or other components between its opening and closing tags, that's what will be displayed as the main content. For example: ```javascript

This is the main content!

 ``` In this case, "This is the main content!" will be displayed between the Header and Footer.

response.value:
The warning message you're seeing is because the version of Node.js you're currently using (`v16.20.2`) is not supported by the version of `@testing-library/dom` (`10.3.1`) you're trying to install. The package requires Node.js version `>=18`.

To resolve this issue, you need to upgrade your Node.js to version 18 or later. You can do this using `nvm` (Node Version Manager), which allows you to manage multiple Node.js versions. If you don't have `nvm` installed, you can install it by following the instructions on the [nvm GitHub page](https://github.com/nvm-sh/nvm).

Here are the steps to upgrade Node.js using `nvm`:

1. Open your terminal.
2. If you haven't installed `nvm` yet, install it by running the installation script from the nvm GitHub page.
3. Once `nvm` is installed, you can install the latest Node.js version (or any specific version >=18) by running:
   ```zsh
   nvm install 18
   ```
4. After the installation is complete, you can switch to the newly installed version by running:
   ```zsh
   nvm use 18
   ```
5. Verify that the correct version of Node.js is now active by running:
   ```zsh
   node -v
   ```

This should resolve the warning about the unsupported engine.

response.value:
The error `ERR_OSSL_EVP_UNSUPPORTED` indicates an issue with OpenSSL when using Node.js, particularly with versions 17 and above, due to the default OpenSSL configuration changing to use more secure algorithms. This issue often arises when running projects that haven't been updated to be compatible with these changes.

To work around this issue, you can set the `NODE_OPTIONS` environment variable to use the legacy provider of OpenSSL. This tells Node.js to allow the use of the older, less secure algorithms that your project or its dependencies might still be using.

Open your terminal and run the following command to set the environment variable for your current session:

```zsh
export NODE_OPTIONS=--openssl-legacy-provider
```

Then, try running your `npm start` command again:

```zsh
npm start
```

If this resolves your issue and you need to make this change persistent across terminal sessions, you can add the `export NODE_OPTIONS=--openssl-legacy-provider` line to your `.zshrc` file (or the appropriate shell configuration file if you're using a shell other than Zsh):

1. Open your `.zshrc` file in a text editor, for example, using `nano`:

   ```zsh
   nano ~/.zshrc
   ```

2. Add the following line at the end of the file:

   ```plaintext
   export NODE_OPTIONS=--openssl-legacy-provider
   ```

3. Save and close the file. If you're using `nano`, you can do this by pressing `Ctrl + X`, then `Y` to confirm, and `Enter` to save.

4. To apply the changes, either restart your terminal or source your `.zshrc` file with:

   ```zsh
   source ~/.zshrc
   ```

This should allow you to bypass the `ERR_OSSL_EVP_UNSUPPORTED` error for your project.

message.text: how to run python in venv

parts.text: how to run python in venv

response.value:
To run Python within a virtual environment (venv) on a Mac, follow these steps:

1. **Create a Virtual Environment**: If you haven't already created a virtual environment, you can do so by navigating to your project directory in the terminal and running:
   ```bash
   python3 -m venv myvenv
   ```
   Replace `myvenv` with the name you want to give to your virtual environment.

2. **Activate the Virtual Environment**: Before running Python, you need to activate the virtual environment. You can do this with the following command:
   ```bash
   source myvenv/bin/activate
   ```
   Again, replace `myvenv` with the name of your virtual environment. Once activated, your terminal prompt will change to indicate that you are now working inside the virtual environment.

3. **Run Python**: Now that your virtual environment is activated, any Python command you run will use the Python interpreter and any Python packages installed in the virtual environment. To run Python, simply type:
   ```bash
   python
   ```
   Or, if you have a specific Python script you want to run, you can do so by specifying the script's filename:
   ```bash
   python script_name.py
   ```

4. **Deactivate the Virtual Environment**: When you're done working in the virtual environment, you can deactivate it by running:
   ```bash
   deactivate
   ```
   This will return you to the system's default Python interpreter.

Remember, each time you start a new terminal session and want to work within your virtual environment, you'll need to activate it again using the `source myvenv/bin/activate` command.

response.value:
The error you're encountering indicates that the `dot` executable from Graphviz is not found in your system's PATH. Graphviz is a package that provides a way to create and render graphs described in the DOT language, and `dot` is one of its tools used for drawing directed graphs as part of layout processing.

To resolve this issue, you need to install Graphviz and ensure its executables are accessible in your system's PATH. Since you're using a Mac, you can install Graphviz using Homebrew, a package manager for macOS. Here's how you can do it:

1. Open your terminal.
2. If you haven't installed Homebrew yet, you can install it by running the following command (this command is directly from the Homebrew website and may change, so if it doesn't work, check their website for the latest installation instructions):
   ```zsh
   /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
   ```
3. Once Homebrew is installed, you can install Graphviz by running:
   ```zsh
   brew install graphviz
   ```
4. After the installation is complete, you can verify that `dot` is correctly installed by running:
   ```zsh
   dot -V
   ```
   This should print the version of Graphviz if it was successfully installed.

5. Try running your `python3 architecture.py` command again after installing Graphviz.

This should resolve the `ExecutableNotFound` error related to the missing `dot` executable.

message.text: how to adjust the space between the components in the diagram

parts.text: how to adjust the space between the components in the diagram

response.value:
To adjust the space between components in a diagram created with the `diagrams` library in Python, you can use the `graph_attr` attribute in the `Diagram` context manager to customize various Graphviz attributes, including spacing. The `nodesep` and `ranksep` attributes control the spacing between nodes horizontally and vertically, respectively.

- `nodesep`: increases or decreases the space between nodes at the same rank, i.e., side by side.
- `ranksep`: increases or decreases the space between ranks, i.e., the vertical distance between levels of nodes.

Here's how you can adjust the space between components in your diagram:

```python
from diagrams import Diagram, Cluster, Edge
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB, Route53
from diagrams.aws.devtools import Codepipeline, Codebuild
from diagrams.aws.general import Client
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
from diagrams.onprem.container import Docker
from diagrams.onprem.monitoring import Prometheus, Grafana
from diagrams.programming.language import Python
from diagrams.programming.framework import React

with Diagram("Bookstore Application Architecture", show=False, graph_attr={'nodesep': '1.0', 'ranksep': '2.0'}):
    client = Client("User")
    internet = Internet("Internet")
    dns = Route53("DNS")

    with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
        github = React("GitHub Actions")
        pipeline = Codepipeline("CodePipeline")
        build = Codebuild("CodeBuild")

    with Cluster("AWS Cloud"):
        lb = ELB("Load Balancer")

        with Cluster("Backend Service"):
            backend = EC2("Backend (Node.js)")
            db = RDS("Database (MongoDB)")

        with Cluster("Frontend Service"):
            frontend = EC2("Frontend (React)")

        with Cluster("Monitoring"):
            prometheus = Prometheus("Prometheus")
            grafana = Grafana("Graf

    client >> internet >> dns >> lb
    github >> pipeline >> build
    build >> lb
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> frontend
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> backend
    backend >> Edge(label="Database Connection") >> db
    backend >> prometheus
    frontend >> prometheus
    prometheus >> grafana
```

In this example, `nodesep` is set to '1.0' (default is 0.25 inches) and `ranksep` is set to '2.0' (default is equally 0.5 inches), but you can adjust these values to increase or decrease the spacing as needed. The values are in inches, and you can use decimal values for finer control.

message.text: Inside the aws cloud node, give some space between components

parts.text: Inside the aws cloud node, give some space between components

response.value:
To adjust the space between components inside the "AWS Cloud" node in your diagram, you can use the `graph_attr` attribute specifically within the `Cluster` context to customize the spacing for that cluster. This allows you to control the spacing between nodes inside the cluster without affecting the global diagram layout.

Here's how you can adjust the space between components inside the "AWS Cloud" cluster:

```python
from diagrams import Cluster, Diagram, Edge
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB
from diagrams.aws.devtools import Codepipeline, Codebuild
from diagrams.aws.general import Client
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
from diagrams.onprem.container import Docker
from diagrams.onprem.monitoring import Prometheus, Grafana
from diagrams.programming.language import Python
from diagrams.programming.framework import React

with Diagram("Bookstore Application Architecture", show=False):
    client = Client("User")
    internet = Internet("Internet")
    dns = Route53("DNS")

    with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
        github = React("GitHub Actions")
        pipeline = Codepipeline("CodePipeline")
        build = Codebuild("CodeBuild")

    with Cluster("AWS Cloud", graph_attr={'nodesep': '1.0', 'ranksep': '1.0'}):
        lb = ELB("Load Balancer")

        with Cluster("Backend Service"):
            backend = EC2("Backend (Node.js)")
            db = RDS("Database (MongoDB)")

        with Cluster("Frontend Service"):
            frontend = EC2("Frontend (React)")

        with Cluster("Monitoring"):
            prometheus = Prometheus("Prometheus")
            grafana = Grafana("Grafana")

    client >> internet >> dns >> lb
    github >> pipeline >> build
    build >> lb
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> frontend
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> backend
    backend >> Edge(label="Database Connection") >> db
    backend >> prometheus
    frontend >> prometheus
    prometheus >> grafana
```

In this example, the `graph_attr` attribute is applied to the "AWS Cloud" cluster with `nodesep` and `ranksep` set to '1.0'. This increases the horizontal and vertical spacing between the components within the "AWS Cloud" cluster. You can adjust these values as needed to achieve the desired spacing.

message.text: does diagram library has module for github and github action?

parts.text: does diagram library has module for github and github action?

response.value:
The `diagrams` library in Python provides a way to create diagram as code for several providers, including cloud services, programming frameworks, and more. However, as of my last update, the `diagrams` library does not natively include specific modules or nodes for GitHub or GitHub Actions within its standard set of providers.

For representing GitHub or GitHub Actions in your diagrams using the `diagrams` library, you might consider using a generic node to symbolize these services or use the `Custom` node to use a custom image that represents GitHub or GitHub Actions. Here's an example of how you can use a `Custom` node:

```python
from diagrams import Diagram
from diagrams.custom import Custom

with Diagram("GitHub Actions Workflow", show=False):
    github_actions = Custom("GitHub Actions", "./path_to_your_github_actions_icon.png")
```

In this example, replace `"./path_to_your_github_actions_icon.png"` with the path to an image file that represents GitHub Actions. This approach allows you to visually include any service or tool in your diagrams, even if they are not directly supported by the library.

However, for central alignment within clusters specifically, focusing on the overall graph direction and ensuring consistent structure within clusters is key.

Here's how you can modify the clusters to attempt a more centered alignment of components:

1. **Set a global graph direction** using [`graph_attr`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A88%2C%22character%22%3A8%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/__init__.py") in the [`Diagram`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A39%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/__init__.py") context to ensure a consistent layout. You've already set `ranksep`, which controls the distance between ranks (nodes/levels in the diagram).

2. **Use consistent structure within clusters** to help with alignment. For example, ensuring each cluster has a similar layout or number of components can help with visual alignment.

3. **Graph direction (`rankdir`)**: This attribute can be set to `"TB"` (top to bottom), `"LR"` (left to right), `"BT"` (bottom to top), or `"RL"` (right to left). For center alignment, `"TB"` or `"LR"` are most relevant.

Here's an example modification for the "AWS Cloud" cluster to illustrate setting `rankdir`:

```python
with Cluster("AWS Cloud", graph_attr={'ranksep': '1.0', 'rankdir': 'TB'}):
    ...
```

This modification suggests the diagram within this cluster should layout its components from top to bottom, which can help in achieving a more centered appearance for the components within the cluster.

However, it's important to note that the `diagrams` library generates diagrams using Graphviz, and absolute center alignment of components within clusters may not always be achievable through simple attribute adjustments due to the way Graphviz's layout algorithms work. The layout is determined by the relationships (edges) between nodes and the constraints you set via `graph_attr`. Experimenting with different `graph_attr` settings and the structure of your diagram can help achieve a visually balanced layout.

# Creating Architecture Diagrams as Code with Python

In this blog post, we'll explore how to create architecture diagrams as code using Python, focusing on a sample 2-tier bookstore application. This approach allows for version-controlled, easily reproducible, and modifiable diagrams that can evolve alongside your application.

## Why Diagrams as Code?

Diagrams as code offer several advantages over traditional diagramming tools:

- **Version Control**: Changes to diagrams can be tracked over time.
- **Automation**: Diagrams can be automatically updated as part of your CI/CD pipeline.
- **Consistency**: Ensures uniformity in the presentation of your architecture.

## Tools Used

We'll use the [`diagrams`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/__init__.py") Python library, which allows for creating cloud system architecture diagrams using code. It supports various providers, including AWS, GCP, Azure, and more.

## Sample Application: Bookstore 2-Tier Architecture

Our sample application is a simple bookstore with a 2-tier architecture consisting of a frontend and a backend, along with a database. It also includes a CI/CD pipeline and monitoring services.

### Step 1: Setting Up Your Environment

First, ensure you have Python installed. Then, install the [`diagrams`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/__init__.py") library using pip:

```bash
pip install diagrams
```

### Step 2: Writing the Diagram Code

Here's how you can define the architecture of our bookstore application:

```python
from diagrams import Diagram, Cluster, Edge
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB, Route53
from diagrams.aws.general import Client
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
from diagrams.onprem.monitoring import Prometheus, Grafana
from diagrams.programming.framework import React
from diagrams.custom import Custom

with Diagram("Bookstore Application Architecture", show=False):
    with Cluster("User Network"):
        client = Client("User")
        internet = Internet("Internet")

    with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
        with Cluster("Source Code"):
            react = React("React")
            terraform = Custom("Terraform", "./tf.png")
        github_actions = Custom("GitHub Actions", "./ghactions.png")

    with Cluster("AWS Cloud"):
        lb = ELB("Load Balancer")
        dns = Route53("DNS")

        with Cluster("Backend Service"):
            backend = EC2("Backend (Node.js)")
            db = RDS("Database (MongoDB)")

        with Cluster("Frontend Service"):
            frontend = EC2("Frontend (React)")

        with Cluster("Monitoring"):
            prometheus = Prometheus("Prometheus")
            grafana = Grafana("Graf

```

### Step 3: Generating the Diagram

Run your Python script:

```bash
python architecture.py
```

This will generate a PNG image named `Bookstore Application Architecture.png` in the same directory.

### Understanding the Diagram

- **User Network**: Represents the entry point for users, connecting through the internet to our application.
- **CI/CD Pipeline**: Showcases the automation for deploying our React frontend and Terraform configurations.
- **AWS Cloud**: Hosts our application, including the load balancer, DNS service, backend service (Node.js), frontend service (React), and database (MongoDB).
- **Monitoring**: Utilizes Prometheus for monitoring and Grafana for visualization.

### Conclusion

Creating diagrams as code provides a flexible, efficient way to document and share your application architecture. By following the steps outlined above, you can start documenting your own systems in a more maintainable and collaborative manner.

source venv/bin/activate

response.value:
# How to Create Architecture Diagrams as Code for a 2-Tier Bookstore Application

Creating architecture diagrams as code is a modern approach that offers numerous benefits over traditional diagramming methods, including version control, automation, and consistency. This article will guide you through the process of creating an architecture diagram for a 2-tier bookstore application using Python and the [`diagrams`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/__init__.py") library.

## Prerequisites

- Python 3.x installed on your system
- Basic understanding of Python programming
- Familiarity with virtual environments in Python

## Step 1: Setting Up Your Environment

### Create a Virtual Environment

First, navigate to your project directory and create a virtual environment. This environment is a sandbox that allows you to run Python and install packages without affecting your global Python installation.

```bash
python3 -m venv venv
```

### Activate the Virtual Environment

Activate the virtual environment to use it for your project.

- On macOS and Linux:

```bash
source venv/bin/activate
```

- On Windows:

```bash
.\venv\Scripts\activate
```

### Install the `diagrams` Library

With the environment activated, install the `diagrams` library, which enables you to generate architecture diagrams using Python code.

```bash
pip install diagrams
```

## Step 2: Writing the Diagram Code

Create a new Python file named [`architecture.py`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Fbookstore-app%2Farch-diagram%2Farchitecture.py%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/bookstore-app/arch-diagram/architecture.py") and open it in your favorite text editor. Copy the following code into the file. This code defines the architecture of a simple bookstore application with a 2-tier architecture, including a frontend, a backend, a database, a CI/CD pipeline, and monitoring services.

```python
from diagrams import Diagram, Cluster, Edge
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB, Route53
from diagrams.aws.general import Client
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
from diagrams.onprem.monitoring import Prometheus, Grafana
from diagrams.programming.framework import React
from diagrams.custom import Custom

graph_attr={'ranksep': '1.0', 'rankdir': 'TB'}

with Diagram("Bookstore Application Architecture", show=False, graph_attr=graph_attr):
    with Cluster("User Network"):
        client = Client("User")
        internet = Internet("Internet")

    with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
        with Cluster("Source Code"):
            react = React("React")
            terraform = Custom("Terraform", "./tf.png")
        github_actions = Custom("GitHub Actions", "./ghactions.png")

    with Cluster("AWS Cloud"):
        lb = ELB("Load Balancer")
        dns = Route53("DNS")

        with Cluster("Backend Service"):
            backend = EC2("Backend (Node.js)")
            db = RDS("Database (MongoDB)")

        with Cluster("Frontend Service"):
            frontend = EC2("Frontend (React)")

        with Cluster("Monitoring"):
            prometheus = Prometheus("Prometheus")
            grafana = Grafana("Grafana")

    client >> internet >> dns >> lb
    react >> github_actions  
    terraform >> github_actions 
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> frontend
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> backend
    backend >> Edge(label="Database Connection") >> db
    backend >> prometheus
    frontend >> prometheus
    prometheus >> grafana
    github_actions >> Edge(color="blue", style="dashed", label="Deploy to AWS Cloud") >> dns
```

## Step 3: Generating the Diagram

Run the script to generate the architecture diagram. Ensure your virtual environment is activated, then execute:

```bash
python architecture.py
```

This command creates a PNG image named `Bookstore Application Architecture.png` in your project directory, illustrating the architecture of the bookstore application.

## Conclusion

You've now successfully created an architecture diagram as code for a 2-tier bookstore application. This method allows for easy updates, version control, and integration into CI/CD pipelines, making it an efficient tool for modern software development practices.

from diagrams import Diagram, Cluster, Edge
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB, Route53, VPC, Subnet
from diagrams.aws.general import Client
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
from diagrams.onprem.monitoring import Prometheus, Grafana
from diagrams.programming.framework import React
from diagrams.custom import Custom

graph_attr = {'ranksep': '1.0', 'rankdir': 'TB'}

with Diagram("Bookstore Application Architecture", show=False, graph_attr=graph_attr):
    with Cluster("User Network"):
        client = Client("User")
        internet = Internet("Internet")

    with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
        with Cluster("Source Code"):
            react = React("React")
            terraform = Custom("Terraform", "./tf.png")
        github_actions = Custom("GitHub Actions", "./ghactions.png")

    with Cluster("AWS Cloud"):
        with Cluster("VPC"):
            vpc = VPC("VPC")
            with Cluster("Public Subnet"):
                dns = Route53("DNS")
                lb = ELB("Load Balancer")
                public_subnet = Subnet("Public Subnet")
                dns >> lb >> public_subnet

            with Cluster("Private Subnet for Backend"):
                private_subnet_backend = Subnet("Private Subnet")
                backend = EC2("Backend (Node.js)")
                db = RDS("Database (MongoDB)")
                private_subnet_backend >> backend >> db

            with Cluster("Private Subnet for Frontend"):
                private_subnet_frontend = Subnet("Private Subnet")
                frontend = EC2("Frontend (React)")
                private_subnet_frontend >> frontend

        with Cluster("Monitoring"):
            prometheus = Prometheus("Prometheus")
            grafana = Grafana("Grafana")

    client >> internet >> dns
    react >> github_actions
    terraform >> github_actions
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> frontend
    lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> backend
    backend >> Edge(label="Database Connection") >> db
    backend >> prometheus
    frontend >> prometheus
    prometheus >> grafana

    # Connecting CI/CD Pipeline to AWS Cloud
    github_actions >> Edge(color="blue", style="dashed", label="Deploy to AWS Cloud") >> dns
```

message.text:
@workspace /explain Write an explanation for the active selection as paragraphs of text.

```python
from diagrams import Diagram, Cluster, Edge
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB, Route53
from diagrams.aws.general import Client
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
from diagrams.onprem.monitoring import Prometheus, Grafana
from diagrams.programming.framework import React
from diagrams.custom import Custom
graph_attr = {'ranksep': '1.0'} #, 'rankdir': 'TB'}
with Diagram("Two Tier Application Architecture", show=False, graph_attr=graph_attr):
	with Cluster("User Network"):
		client = Client("User")
		internet = Internet("Internet")
	with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
		with Cluster("Source Code"):
			react = React("React")
			terraform = Custom("Terraform", "./tf.png")
		github_actions = Custom("GitHub Actions", "./ghactions.png")
	with Cluster("AWS Cloud"):
		with Cluster("VPC"):
			with Cluster("Public Subnet"):
				dns = Route53("DNS")
				lb = ELB("Load Balancer")
				# public_subnet = Subnet("Public Subnet")
				dns >> lb
			with Cluster("Private Subnet for Backend"):
				# private_subnet_backend = Subnet("Private Subnet")
				backend = EC2("Backend (Node.js)")
				db = RDS("Database (MongoDB)")
				backend >> db
			with Cluster("Private Subnet for Frontend"):
				# private_subnet_frontend = Subnet("Private Subnet")
				frontend = EC2("Frontend (React)")
				# private_subnet_frontend >> frontend
		with Cluster("Monitoring"):
			prometheus = Prometheus("Prometheus")
			grafana = Grafana("Grafana")
	client >> internet >> dns
	react >> github_actions
	terraform >> github_actions
	lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> frontend
	lb >> Edge(label="HTTP/HTTPS") >> backend
	backend >> Edge(label="Database Connection") >> db
	backend >> prometheus
	frontend >> prometheus
	db >> prometheus
	prometheus >> grafana
	# Connecting CI/CD Pipeline to AWS Cloud
	github_actions >> Edge(color="blue", style="dashed", label="Deploy to AWS Cloud") >> dns
	
# Creating Custom Node 
# Custom Node: We can create a custom node to represent the subnet. 
# The diagrams library allows you to create custom nodes with your own images, 
# which can be useful for representing components that are not available as predefined classes.
# from diagrams import Node
# class Subnet(Node):
#    _icon_dir = "path/to/custom/icons"
#    _icon = "subnet.png"
```

This Python script uses the `diagrams` library to create a visual representation of a two-tier application architecture. The architecture is divided into several clusters representing different aspects of the system, including user network, CI/CD pipeline, and AWS Cloud infrastructure, each containing various components.

### User Network
The "User Network" cluster includes a [`Client`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Faws%2Fgeneral.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A10%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/aws/general.py") node representing the user and an [`Internet`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Fonprem%2Fnetwork.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A50%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/onprem/network.py") node. These nodes illustrate the entry point for users accessing the application through the internet.

### CI/CD Pipeline
Within the "CI/CD Pipeline" cluster, there are further subdivisions for "Source Code" and the CI/CD tool itself. The "Source Code" cluster contains nodes for [`React`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Fprogramming%2Fframework.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A58%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/programming/framework.py") and `Terraform`, indicating the technologies used for frontend development and infrastructure as code, respectively. A [`Custom`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Fcustom%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A7%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/custom/__init__.py") node represents "GitHub Actions", a CI/CD tool used for automating the deployment process.

### AWS Cloud
The "AWS Cloud" cluster is subdivided into "VPC", "Monitoring", and their respective subnets. The "VPC" cluster illustrates the network setup within AWS, including public and private subnets. The public subnet contains [`Route53`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Faws%2Fnetwork.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A106%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/aws/network.py") for DNS and an `ELB` (Elastic Load Balancer) for distributing incoming traffic. The private subnets are designated for backend and frontend components, with [`EC2`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Faws%2Fcompute.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A74%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/aws/compute.py") instances representing the backend (Node.js) and frontend (React) servers, and an [`RDS`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Faws%2Fdatabase.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A122%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/aws/database.py") instance for the MongoDB database. The "Monitoring" cluster includes [`Prometheus`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Fonprem%2Fmonitoring.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/onprem/monitoring.py") for monitoring and [`Grafana`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2Fonprem%2Fmonitoring.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A22%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/onprem/monitoring.py") for visualization.

### Connections
The script defines connections between nodes using the `>>` operator and [`Edge`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.venv%2Flib%2Fpython3.12%2Fsite-packages%2Fdiagrams%2F__init__.py%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A436%2C%22character%22%3A6%7D%5D ".venv/lib/python3.12/site-packages/diagrams/__init__.py") objects to represent the flow of data and interactions between components. For example, the user connects to the internet, which then connects to DNS services in AWS. The CI/CD pipeline is connected to the AWS Cloud, indicating deployment actions. Load balancers route traffic to frontend and backend servers, and the backend server connects to the database. Monitoring connections are also depicted, showing how various components send data to Prometheus, which in turn is connected to Grafana for visualization.

### Custom Nodes and Comments
The script includes commented-out sections for creating custom nodes, such as a `Subnet` node, demonstrating how to extend the diagrams library with custom imagery for components not available as predefined classes. This feature allows for more detailed and specific architectural diagrams.

Overall, this script effectively demonstrates how to use the `diagrams` library to create a detailed and visually appealing representation of a two-tier application architecture, showcasing the relationships and interactions between different components within a system.

Given the context provided, I'll explain a general structure and approach for creating an architecture diagram in Python using the `diagrams` library. This explanation assumes a typical use case for the library, focusing on creating a cloud infrastructure diagram, which is a common application of the `diagrams` library.

### Importing the Library
First, you need to import the necessary components from the `diagrams` library. This includes the main `Diagram` class and various node classes representing different services and components (e.g., AWS services, on-premises servers, CI/CD tools).

```python
from diagrams import Diagram
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.network import ELB, Route53
from diagrams.onprem.client import User
from diagrams.onprem.network import Internet
# Additional imports as needed
```

### Setting Up the Diagram Context
Using the `Diagram` class, you define the context of your diagram. This includes setting a title, filename, and any global attributes like diagram direction or outformat.

```python
with Diagram("Two-Tier Architecture", show=False, filename="two_tier_architecture"):
    # Diagram components go here
```

### Defining Components and Clusters
Inside the diagram context, you define the components of your architecture. You can group related components using clusters for better organization and visual clarity.

```python
from diagrams.aws.network import VPC
from diagrams.aws.compute import EC2
from diagrams.aws.database import RDS
from diagrams.aws.monitoring import CloudWatch
from diagrams.onprem.ci import Jenkins
from diagrams.onprem.vcs import Github

with Diagram("Two-Tier Architecture", show=False, filename="two_tier_architecture"):
    user = User("User")
    internet = Internet("Internet")
    
    with Cluster("CI/CD Pipeline"):
        source_code = Github("Source Code")
        ci_tool = Jenkins("CI/CD")
    
    with Cluster("AWS Cloud"):
        with Cluster("VPC"):
            with Cluster("Public Subnet"):
                dns = Route53("DNS")
                lb = ELB("Load Balancer")
            with Cluster("Private Subnet"):
                web_server = EC2("Web Server")
                db = RDS("Database")
        monitoring = CloudWatch("Monitoring")
```

### Connecting Components
After defining the components, you connect them to illustrate the flow and relationships between different parts of your architecture. Connections can represent network traffic, data flow, or any other interaction.

```python
user >> internet >> dns >> lb >> web_server
web_server >> db
web_server >> monitoring
```

### Custom Nodes and Advanced Features
The `diagrams` library allows for customization and advanced features like creating custom nodes if a specific component is not available in the library. You can also adjust attributes like color, label, and connections dynamically based on your requirements.

```python
# Example of a custom node
class CustomNode(Custom):
    _icon_dir = "path/to/custom/icons"
    icon = "custom_icon.png"

custom_node = CustomNode("Custom Service")
```

### Generating the Diagram
Once all components are defined and connected, exiting the `with Diagram(...):` block automatically generates and saves the diagram to the specified file. If `show=True`, it also displays the diagram.

This breakdown covers the basic structure and components involved in creating an architecture diagram with the `diagrams` library in Python. The actual implementation details can vary based on the specific requirements of the architecture being diagrammed.

response.value:
To run a Python script in Visual Studio Code on a Mac, follow these steps:

1. **Open the Terminal in VS Code**:
   - You can open the terminal by selecting `View` > `Terminal` from the top menu or by using the shortcut `Ctrl + ` (backtick).

2. **Navigate to the Directory**:
   - Ensure you are in the directory where your Python script is located. You can use the `cd` command to change directories. For example:
     ```sh
     cd path/to/your/script
     ```

3. **Run the Python Script**:
   - Use the `python` or `python3` command followed by the script name. For example:
     ```sh
     python3 your_script.py
     ```

If you have any specific requirements or dependencies, make sure they are installed in your environment. You can use `pip` to install any required packages.

If you encounter any issues, please provide more details so I can assist you further.

4. **Usage**: Explain how to deploy the infrastructure.

6. **Variables**: List the variables used in the [`main.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/tf-multitier/multi-tier-app/main.tf") file.
7. **Outputs**: Mention any outputs if applicable.
8. **Contributing**: Provide guidelines for contributing.
9. **License**: Specify the license if applicable.

### Code

```markdown
# Terraform Multi-Tier Application

This project sets up a multi-tier application infrastructure using Terraform on AWS. It includes VPC, EC2 instances, RDS, and an ELB.

## Prerequisites

- [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/downloads.html) v0.12+
- AWS Account
- AWS CLI configured with appropriate credentials

## Setup Instructions

1. **Clone the Repository**:
   ```sh
   git clone https://github.com/your-repo/terraform-multi-tier.git
   cd terraform-multi-tier
   ```

2. **Initialize Terraform**:
   ```sh
   terraform init
   ```

3. **Create a `terraform.tfvars` file**:
   ```sh
   touch terraform.tfvars
   ```

4. **Add your variable values to `terraform.tfvars`**:
   ```hcl
   region = "us-west-2"
   vpc_cidr = "10.0.0.0/16"
   public_subnet_cidrs = ["10.0.1.0/24", "10.0.2.0/24"]
   private_subnet_cidrs = ["10.0.3.0/24", "10.0.4.0/24"]
   ami_id = "ami-0abcdef1234567890"
   instance_type = "t2.micro"
   desired_capacity = 2
   max_size = 3
   min_size = 1
   db_identifier = "mydb"
   allocated_storage = 20
   engine = "mysql"
   engine_version = "5.7"
   instance_class = "db.t2.micro"
   db_name = "mydatabase"
   username = "admin"
   password = "password"
   ```

## Usage

1. **Plan the Infrastructure**:
   ```sh
   terraform plan
   ```

2. **Apply the Infrastructure**:
   ```sh
   terraform apply
   ```

3. **Destroy the Infrastructure**:
   ```sh
   terraform destroy
   ```

## Modules

- **VPC**: Sets up the Virtual Private Cloud with public and private subnets.
- **EC2**: Provisions EC2 instances within the VPC.
- **RDS**: Sets up an RDS instance within the private subnets.
- **LB**: Configures an Elastic Load Balancer for the EC2 instances.

## Variables

- `region`: AWS region to deploy resources.
- `vpc_cidr`: CIDR block for the VPC.
- `public_subnet_cidrs`: List of CIDR blocks for public subnets.
- `private_subnet_cidrs`: List of CIDR blocks for private subnets.
- `ami_id`: AMI ID for EC2 instances.
- `instance_type`: EC2 instance type.
- `desired_capacity`: Desired number of EC2 instances.
- `max_size`: Maximum number of EC2 instances.
- `min_size`: Minimum number of EC2 instances.
- `db_identifier`: Identifier for the RDS instance.
- `allocated_storage`: Storage allocated for the RDS instance.
- `engine`: Database engine for RDS.
- `engine_version`: Version of the database engine.
- `instance_class`: Instance class for RDS

vulnerabilities.title: hardcoded-credentials
vulnerabilities.description: Embedding credentials in source code risks unauthorized access

response.value:
- `db_name`: Name of the database.
- `username`: Username for the database.
- `password`: Password for the database.

## Contributing

Contributions are welcome! Please open an issue or submit a pull request for any changes.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License.
```

This README provides a comprehensive guide to setting up and using the Terraform multi-tier application infrastructure. Adjust the repository URL and any other specific details as needed.

response.value:
To create the S3 bucket and DynamoDB table required for the Terraform backend, you can use the AWS CLI. Here are the steps:

### Step-by-Step Instructions

1. **Open Terminal**:
   - Open the terminal in Visual Studio Code or your preferred terminal application.

2. **Create S3 Bucket**:
   - Use the following command to create an S3 bucket. Replace [`my-terraform-state-bucket`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22my-terraform-state-bucket%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A2%2C%22character%22%3A22%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition") with your desired bucket name and [`us-west-2`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22us-west-2%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A4%2C%22character%22%3A22%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition") with your desired region.
   ```sh
   aws s3api create-bucket --bucket my-terraform-state-bucket --region us-west-2 --create-bucket-configuration LocationConstraint=us-west-2
   ```

3. **Enable Versioning on S3 Bucket**:
   - Enable versioning on the S3 bucket to keep track of the state file versions.
   ```sh
   aws s3api put-bucket-versioning --bucket my-terraform-state-bucket --versioning-configuration Status=Enabled
   ```

4. **Create DynamoDB Table**:
   - Use the following command to create a DynamoDB table for state locking. Replace [`terraform-lock-table`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22terraform-lock-table%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A2%2C%22character%22%3A25%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition") with your desired table name.
   ```sh
   aws dynamodb create-table --table-name terraform-lock-table --attribute-definitions AttributeName=LockID,AttributeType=S --key-schema AttributeName=LockID,KeyType=HASH --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 --region us-west-2
   ```

### Summary of Commands

```sh
# Create S3 bucket
aws s3api create-bucket --bucket my-terraform-state-bucket --region us-west-2 --create-bucket-configuration LocationConstraint=us-west-2

# Enable versioning on S3 bucket
aws s3api put-bucket-versioning --bucket my-terraform-state-bucket --versioning-configuration Status=Enabled

# Create DynamoDB table
aws dynamodb create-table --table-name terraform-lock-table --attribute-definitions AttributeName=LockID,AttributeType=S --key-schema AttributeName=LockID,KeyType=HASH --provisioned-throughput ReadCapacityUnits=1,WriteCapacityUnits=1 --region us-west-2
```

After running these commands, your S3 bucket and DynamoDB table will be ready for use with Terraform.

Here's a [`.gitignore`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.gitignore%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/.gitignore") file tailored for a Terraform project:

```plaintext
# Local .terraform directories
**/.terraform/*

# .tfstate files
*.tfstate
*.tfstate.*

# Crash log files
crash.log

# Exclude all .tfvars files, which are likely to contain sensitive data, such as passwords
*.tfvars

# Ignore override files as they are usually used to override resources locally and should not be shared
override.tf
override.tf.json
*_override.tf
*_override.tf.json

# Include .terraformrc and terraform.rc files as they are user-specific configuration files
.terraformrc
terraform.rc

# Ignore any plan output files
*.tfplan
```

This [`.gitignore`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2F.gitignore%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/.gitignore") file ensures that sensitive and unnecessary files are not tracked by Git, keeping your repository clean and secure.

response.value:
The last command run in the terminal was `terraform plan`. This command generates an execution plan, showing what actions Terraform will take to achieve the desired state defined in your configuration files.

### Summary of the Output

1. **State Locking**:
   - Terraform acquires a state lock to prevent concurrent operations on the same state file.

2. **Planned Actions**:
   - Terraform plans to create several resources, including:
     - `aws_db_subnet_group` for RDS
     - `aws_internet_gateway` for the VPC
     - Multiple `aws_subnet` resources (both public and private)
     - `aws_vpc` for the main VPC

3. **Errors Encountered**:
   - **Invalid Value for Input Variable**:
     - **Module `ec2`**: The `security_groups` variable expects a list of strings, but it received `[module.vpc.public_subnet_ids]`, which is not a string.
     - **Module `rds`**: The `security_group_ids` variable expects a list of strings, but it received `[module.vpc.private_subnet_ids]`, which is not a string.
     - **Module `lb`**: The `security_groups` variable expects a list of strings, but it received `[module.vpc.public_subnet_ids]`, which is not a string.

### Explanation of Errors

- **Type Mismatch**:
  - The errors indicate that the variables `security_groups` and `security_group_ids` are expected to be lists of strings (security group IDs), but the provided values are lists of subnet IDs instead.

### Next Steps

1. **Check Variable Definitions**:
   - Ensure that the variables `security_groups` and `security_group_ids` in your `main.tf` file are assigned the correct values (security group IDs).

2. **Correct the Assignments**:
   - Update the assignments in `main.tf` to provide the correct security group IDs.

Example correction:
```hcl
module "ec2" {
  # Correct the security_groups assignment
  security_groups = [module.vpc.security_group_id]
}

module "rds" {
  # Correct the security_group_ids assignment
  security_group_ids = [module.vpc.security_group_id]
}

module "lb" {
  # Correct the security_groups assignment
  security_groups = [module.vpc.security_group_id]
}
```

Make sure to replace `module.vpc.security_group_id` with the actual variable or output that provides the security group IDs.

message.text: Create an ec2 instance with modularised appraoch with vpc, subnet, and sg, created thru modules

response.value:
To create an EC2 instance using a modular approach with VPC, subnet, and security group created through modules, follow these steps:

### Step-by-Step Instructions

1. **Create the Directory Structure**:
   - Organize your Terraform project with separate directories for each module.

   ```plaintext
   terraform-project/
    main.tf
    variables.tf
    outputs.tf
    modules/
       vpc/
          main.tf
          variables.tf
          outputs.tf
       subnet/
          main.tf
          variables.tf
          outputs.tf
       security-group/
           main.tf
           variables.tf
           outputs.tf
    ec2/
        main.tf
        variables.tf
        outputs.tf
   ```

2. **Define the VPC Module**:

   [`modules/vpc/main.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/tf-multitier/multi-tier-app/main.tf"):
   ```hcl
   resource "aws_vpc" "main" {
     cidr_block = var.cidr_block
   }

   output "vpc_id" {
     value = aws_vpc.main.id
   }
   ```

   [`modules/vpc/variables.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22modules%2Fvpc%2Fvariables.tf%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A14%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition"):
   ```hcl
   variable "cidr_block" {
     description = "The CIDR block for the VPC"
     type        = string
   }
   ```

   [`modules/vpc/outputs.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22modules%2Fvpc%2Foutputs.tf%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A14%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition"):
   ```hcl
   output "vpc_id" {
     value = aws_vpc.main.id
   }
   ```

3. **Define the Subnet Module**:

   [`modules/subnet/main.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/tf-multitier/multi-tier-app/main.tf"):
   ```hcl
   resource "aws_subnet" "main" {
     vpc_id            = var.vpc_id
     cidr_block        = var.cidr_block
     availability_zone = var.availability_zone
   }

   output "subnet_id" {
     value = aws_subnet.main.id
   }
   ```

   [`modules/subnet/variables.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22modules%2Fsubnet%2Fvariables.tf%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A14%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition"):
   ```hcl
   variable "vpc_id" {
     description = "The ID of the VPC"
     type        = string
   }

   variable "cidr_block" {
     description = "The CIDR block for the subnet"
     type        = string
   }

   variable "availability_zone" {
     description = "The availability zone for the subnet"
     type        = string
   }
   ```

   [`modules/subnet/outputs.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22modules%2Fsubnet%2Foutputs.tf%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A14%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition"):
   ```hcl
   output "subnet_id" {
     value = aws_subnet.main.id
   }
   ```

4. **Define the Security Group Module**:

   [`modules/security-group/main.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/tf-multitier/multi-tier-app/main.tf"):
   ```hcl
   resource "aws_security_group" "main" {
     vpc_id = var.vpc_id

     ingress {
       from_port   = 22
       to_port     = 22
       protocol    = "tcp"
       cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
     }

     egress {
       from_port   = 0
       to_port     = 0
       protocol    = "-1"
       cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
     }
   }

   output "security_group_id" {
     value = aws_security_group.main.id
   }
   ```

   [`modules/security-group/variables.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22modules%2Fsecurity-group%2Fvariables.tf%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A14%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition"):
   ```hcl
   variable "vpc_id" {
     description = "The ID of the VPC"
     type        = string
   }
   ```

   [`modules/security-group/outputs.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22modules%2Fsecurity-group%2Foutputs.tf%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A46%2C%22character%22%3A14%7D%7D%5D%5D "Go to definition"):
   ```hcl
   output "security_group_id" {
     value = aws_security_group.main.id
   }
   ```

5. **Define the EC2 Module**:

   [`ec2/main.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/tf-multitier/multi-tier-app/main.tf"):
   ```hcl
   resource "aws_instance" "main" {
     ami           = var.ami
     instance_type = var.instance_type
     subnet_id     = var.subnet_id
     security_groups = [var.security_group_id]

     tags = {
       Name = "MyEC2Instance"
     }
   }
   ```

   `ec2/variables.tf`:
   ```hcl
   variable "ami" {
     description = "The AMI ID for the EC2 instance"
     type        = string
   }

   variable "instance_type" {
     description = "The instance type for the EC2 instance"
     type        = string
   }

   variable "subnet_id" {
     description = "The ID of the subnet"
     type        = string
   }

   variable "security_group_id" {
     description = "The ID of the security group"
     type        = string
   }
   ```

   `ec2/outputs.tf`:
   ```hcl
   output "instance_id" {
     value = aws_instance.main.id
   }
   ```

6. **Define the Main Configuration**:

   [`main.tf`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fgsaravanan%2FDocuments%2Fgithub%2Fgpt_demos%2Ftf-multitier%2Fmulti-tier-app%2Fmain.tf%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/gsaravanan/Documents/github/gpt_demos/tf-multitier/multi-tier-app/main.tf"):
   ```hcl
   provider "aws" {
     region = "us-west-2"
   }

   module "vpc" {
     source    = "./modules/vpc"
     cidr_block = "10.0.0.0/16"
   }

   module "subnet" {
     source            = "./modules/subnet"
     vpc_id            = module.vpc.vpc_id
     cidr_block        = "10.0.1.0/24"
     availability_zone = "us-west-2a"
   }

   module "security_group" {
     source = "./modules/security-group"
     vpc_id = module.vpc.vpc_id
   }

   module "ec2" {
     source            = "./ec2"
     ami               = "ami-0abcdef1234567890"
     instance_type     = "t2.micro"
     subnet_id         = module.subnet.subnet_id
     security_group_id = module.security_group.security_group_id
   }
   ```

7. **Define Variables and Outputs**:

   `variables.tf`:
   ```hcl
   # Define any global variables if needed
   ```

   `outputs.tf`:
   ```hcl
   output "instance_id" {
     value = module.ec2.instance_id
   }
   ```

### Summary

This setup modularizes the creation of a VPC, subnet, security group, and EC2 instance. Each module is responsible for a specific part of the infrastructure, making the configuration more organized and reusable. Adjust the variables and configurations as needed for your specific use case.
